holdings.text: Section 56 of the Bombay Police Act, 1951 is not unconstitutional as it does not contravene Article 19 of the Constitution
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent in Gurbachan Singh v. State of Bombay upholding similar provision in City of Bombay Police Act s27; no attempt to distinguish

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid it must be held that section 56 of the Act is number unconstitutional -and that the orders passed against the petitioners are number invalid. These applications must stand dismissed.

holdings.text: If res integra, difficulty in upholding section 56(b) due to lack of demarcation to serious offences and two-year period without review intervals is unreasonable
holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter: provision too broad, long duration without periodic review interferes unreasonably with personal liberty; externment potentially more harmful than detention

State of Bombay 1 as follows- The law is certainly an extraordinary, one and has been made only to meet those exceptional cases where numberwitnesses for fear of violence to their person or property are willing to depose publicly against certain bad characters whose presence-in certain areas companystitutes a menace to the safety of the public residing therein.

precedents.cited_proposition: The law is an extraordinary one made only to meet exceptional cases where no witnesses for fear of violence are willing to depose publicly against bad characters
